div1.head: Newspaper clipping, [1902]
div1.p:
Secretary Root, in calling attention to
the fact that a battery at Fort Howard
has been named after Dr. Lazear, brings
to mind again the splendid heroism of
that young man who gave up his life
that others might live. We cannot hear
the story too often. Dr. Lazear was a
young Marylander, who, after studying
at Johns Hopkins and Columbia Univer-
sities, entered the medical profession and
secured an appointment as surgeon in
the United States Army. He was as-
signed to laboratory work in Cuba, and
in 1900 was made a member of a special
Government commission to investigate
the prevalence of yellow fever near Ha-
vana. There came a time in the work of
the committee when further progress de-
pended absolutely upon human experi-
ment. There was no other way of prov-
ing the transmission of the disease from
mosquito to man. Then Dr. Lazear sub-
jected himself to infection. He was taken
with the fever and died on September 25,
1900. The results of his sacrifice are well
known. Havana, so long a hotbed of the
disease, has been freed from yellow fever.
Other lands have profited by it, and so
great an authority as Dr. Welch has pro-
nounced the commission's discovery one
of inestimable value. Lazear's act was
not that of an unthinking enthusiast or
a reckless gambler. It was the deed of
a trained thinker, fully aware of the
consequences, yet also fully aware of
the necessity for it. It was a deed of
glorious bravery, not matchless only be-
cause at intervals of the world's history,
when occasion called, other men have
been equally careless of self for the
world's good. But it is something to be
remembered with a thrill as long as the
record of the deed shall survive.
